awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: New Efficient Algorithms for Complex Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research project is to develop new super-efficient, reliable, and robust algorithms solving modern challenges that arise in mastering complex data. For example, to successfully employ technological innovations such as autonomous vehicles it is necessary to synergistically and quickly operate with data that may be high-dimensional, distributed, erroneous, or even incomplete. This research project will advance the state of the art in computing with such diverse data by developing new theoretical foundations for problems that lie at the heart of communication-efficient distributed computation, coding and information theory, and machine learning. The project will also involve graduate and undergraduate student research and mentoring, and the results will achieve wide dissemination though workshops, conferences, online venues, and as teaching material.

The project will focus on four specific goals. The first one consists in abstracting global and local models that capture real-world data pertinent to distributed computation, learning and testing, and error-correction. The second goal is to design efficient algorithms and demonstrate limiting lower bounds in these models. The third goal is to illuminate the interplay between structure and fast computation, especially in the models mentioned above. Finally, the project aims to develop novel analysis techniques that are both data-specific, as well as unifying. These goals will likely be achieved by bridging insights from diverse areas of mathematics and computer science, including learning and coding theory, sublinear algorithms, cryptography, geometry, statistics and optimizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project investigated fast, reliable, and robust algorithmic solutions to computational problems on data that may be arising from a diverse set of application domains, including communications, DNA storage, network connectivity, and machine learning.

Specifically, one of the challenges of modern DNA storage systems is to recover data despite insertion and deletion of information symbols. Additionally, super-fast recovery of small data fragments is a highly desirable feature in designing modern biotechnology. The project addressed such challenges on the one hand by initiating a systematic study of locally decodable codes that can withstand many deleted or inserted symbols, and on the other hand by making contributions to the study of the famous trace-reconstruction problem. In particular, the strongest technical outcome of this research direction shows that codes that only make constantly many probes into the received data must have codeword length of size exponential in the message length. The result brought up many further avenues of research and generated follow-up work.

In another direction of research, the PI addressed network connectivity problems, in particular the approximability of several degree-constrained subgraphs problems, and of graph spanner problems. These fundamental combinatorial problems have a wide range of applications in distributed computation, data structures, routing schemes, and property testing. The results on online directed spanner problems and their further extensions to weighted variants are the first to show efficient algorithms with sublinear approximation/competitive ratios and are still state of the art.

In terms of significance to machine learning, one of the research outcomes was introducing the model of list learning with attribute noise and proving upper and lower bounds on learning natural hypothesis classes, such as conjunctions and parities. List learning with noisy attributes is relevant to scientific modeling, where one seeks to model data dependencies despite errors in the recordings of the data. A further direction relevant to machine learning resulted in solving a long-standing open problem on the complexity of the maximum likelihood estimation of determinantal point processes, which are processes employed in settings where one needs to select diverse sets of elements that are also representative of the data. Such processes were first observed in quantum statistical physics, and have since found many applications in data analysis, including signal processing, segmentation and summarization, and clustering, among others.

In addition to the scientific results summarized above, the project helped train and support several PhD students, who have now graduated, and are continuing to make contributions to either academia or industry research.
